EditorData.AnimationTags: [REUSE] HALSIN raises his hand to the player's head (no contact) and pulls it away once realizing what he senses [CodyM]
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows whatâ€™s inside you

Text.Value: I am Halsin - First Druid of the Emerald Grove... and I sense you have a problem you seek my help with.

EditorData.NodeContext: Knowing - referring to the player's tadpole problem

Text.Value: ...It's true. I can feel it right now. Oakfather preserve you, child.
What about my problem? I need to get to Moonrise Towers.
The shadows could not have tempted her if I had taught her as I should have.
I'm afraid your pupil, Kagha, is dead.
Your path will soon take you away from the grove, I feel. Your efforts will not be forgotten.
Soon. First I must set matters to rights in the grove. And you should celebrate your victory.
I might go mad... I might be mad...
Rest. Heal. Celebrate if you wish. Mourn if you must. Come morning, we shall discuss delivering you from your parasite.

EditorData.NodeContext: 'We've been through a lot. Take some time to gather yourself'

Text.Value: Take tonight to rest, recuperate - celebrate. Tomorrow, we can strike out.

EditorData.logicalname: ALREADY SAID HE'D JOIN CAMP TOMORROW

Text.Value: The other druids are dead. They turned on us - we had to defend ourselves.
With the leadership dead, no attack will be mounted on the grove. I am in your debt, my friend.

EditorData.logicalname: Goblin Leadership Dead / Has not met

Text.Value: Take tonight to rest, recuperate - celebrate. Tomorrow, I'll join your camp so I can help with the trials yet to come.
What happens next?
I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
There's something else I wanted to ask about getting to Moonrise Towers.
Oakfather... a mind flayer spawn. You should be far gone by now.
Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
After being dormant for so long, your infection is unlikely to produce new symptoms spontaneously.
Kagha... poor child. The grove will be a dimmer place without her potential.

EditorData.NodeContext: Bowed head. Mournful, Kagha was misguided, but he'll miss her.,

Text.Value: The grove stands. Nature prevails. And again, I am in your debt.

EditorData.NodeContext: Content and grateful. Looks around at his surrounds in general, happy to be home,

Text.Value: It's no coincidence that we found each other, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
I was an unwilling guest of the goblins - but your efforts left them in disarray and I was able to escape.

EditorData.logicalname: Alias (ALREADY SAID HE'D JOIN CAMP TOMORROW)

Text.Value: But the grove still stands even if they do not - thanks to you.
I don't know what you mean. What problem?
The journey to Moonrise Towers, and all the dangers that that entails.
The grove is nature's beating heart - I was glad to help save it.
I acted to save my kin, not this place.
I hope this grove of yours is worth the bloodshed.
Speak to Rath - he will reward you for your efforts.

EditorData.NodeContext: Referring to one of his underlings

Text.Value: I was not here to guide them. Now they rest forever, while I carry the weight of my failings.
But you are right - you had no choice. I failed her, long before you arrived.
I can't remember anything... All my life before the parasite...
There's a chokehold of magic, binding the creature to you. Any efforts to remove it would almost certainly kill you - or worse.
The grove is nature's beating heart - I was glad to help save it.
I acted to save my kin, not this place.
I did as I wished to. I never cared if this place was saved or not.
This place means nothing to me, but a great deal to you, it seems. I hope the blood price was worth it.
I hope this grove of yours was worth the bloodshed.
Yes. I have a mind flayer parasite inside my head. I want your help removing it.
The grove stands. Nature prevails. I owe you my thanks - and an introduction.

EditorData.NodeContext: Grateful. this is the first time Halsin has met you (if you missed him in the goblin camp)

Text.Value: I don't know.
Enjoy the respite. Come morning, we have matters to discuss.
Wait - how did you get here?
As for what you've done for the grove, speak to Rath. He will see to your reward.
Tomorrow morning, we shall discuss what is to come.

EditorData.NodeContext: This is a much anticipated converation that he's aluding to.

Text.Value: ...That problem. You're infected with the mind flayer spawn, aren't you? Oakfather preserve you, child.
Yes, you did. You acted according to your instincts, to nature. This is my fault.

EditorData.NodeContext: Mournful, bowed head. He blames himself rather than the player.

Text.Value: It sounds as if you've been done a world of harm. Cling onto the life you yet have.
But the grove still stands even if she does not - thanks to you.
If only you had come to this place in more peaceful times. You'd have been a welcome addition.
And yet save it you did. I am grateful no matter what your motivations.
Believe me, it is. The span of a mortal life isn't enough to grasp the importance of this place. Its roots touch everything.
But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
But that's tomorrow's problem. Take some time for yourself tonight - rest, celebrate. Come morning, I'll be by your side.
Soon. Remember the dangers I told you about - there'll be plenty of time to face them.
No more delays. Tell me what you know about getting to Moonrise.
Leave.
Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
How is this possible...?

Synopsis: The Druid Grove has been saved (because either the attacking force was repelled or its leaders were assassinated) and Halsin returns. He thanks the player and reacts to events that may have transpired in the grove during his absence. He's previously promised to help the player with their tadpole problem, but he defers this discussion until the next morning after the victory celebrations.
